node.title: Rain relentless in Tairāwhiti after floods, slips
node.description: The rain still has not stopped in Tairāwhiti - despite a slight reprieve it is back in full force along with strong winds, hitting the already sodden region. Audio

node.title: Man drowns at Whangamatā beach
node.description: Police and ambulance responded to reports of a man drowning at Whangamatā Beach about 4.45pm today.

node.title: Owners of Eastern European pop-up hold fundraiser for Ukraine
node.description: Brooklyn-based chef couple Trina and Jessica Quinn are on a mission to cut through misconceptions about Eastern European cuisine, and help those affected by the war in Ukraine.

node.title: The birth of NYC's Universal Hip-Hop Museum
node.description: The Bronx — the legendary birthplace of hip-hop — is getting a museum dedicated to the music and culture.

node.title: McCarthy defends Thomas' ability to rule on Jan. 6 committee
node.description: CBS News and the Washington Post revealed texts showing Ginni Thomas texted Meadows about how to overturn 2020 election.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 15,871 new cases, 13 deaths, 899 in hospital
node.description: Health officials are reporting 13 more people with Covid-19 have died, with 15,871 new community cases reported today.

node.title: ICE discontinues or limits use of 4 detention facilities, citing conditions
node.description: As of earlier this month, ICE was holding just over 20,000 immigrants in its detention system, which consists mainly of county jails and for-profit prisons.

node.title: U.S. oil companies don't plan to drill more, despite high prices
node.description: Rather than give consumers relief at the pump, many oil and gas executives are sending profits to investors.

node.title: Families want serial killer case reopened decades after 16 murders
node.description: Most of the victims were attacked in cars, during or just after having sex.

node.title: This week on "Sunday Morning" (March 27)
node.description: A look at the features for this week's broadcast of the #1 Sunday morning news program

node.title: Why Ginni Thomas' texts with Mark Meadows could be "tricky" for Congress
node.description: Copies of the text messages were obtained by CBS News chief election and campaign correspondent Robert Costa and Bob Woodward of The Washington Post.

node.title: Applebee's exec says high gas prices will let owners cut pay
node.description: A leaked memo said that because its pool of workers live "paycheck to paycheck," high gas prices will "force people back into the work force."

node.title: Most Americans see cryptocurrency as a risky investment
node.description: Adults under 45 are far more likely than older adults to invest in cryptocurrency.

node.title: Man dies trying to parachute from high-rise as teen daughter watched
node.description: The 48-year-old man was attempting to parachute from the 23-story Palisade UTC luxury apartment complex, police said.

node.title: Philadelphia police say September mass shooting was hired hit
node.description: Steven Jones was standing on a crowded sidewalk in September when the shooter opened fire from inside a car, killing Jones and injuring six more.

node.title: Clarence Thomas discharged after week-long hospital stay
node.description: The associate justice was admitted with an infection on March 18 after experiencing "flu-like symptoms."

node.title: Japan approves boosted funding for ongoing U.S. military presence
node.description: Lawmakers approved the $8.6 billion, 5-year host-nation budget with threats looming large in the background from China, North Korea and Russia.

node.title: Manchin says he'll vote yes to confirm Jackson to Supreme Court
node.description: The Democratic senator's yes vote greatly improves her odds of confirmation.

node.title: Omicron deaths of J&J recipients higher than other vaccinated Americans
node.description: Rates of breakthrough COVID-19 cases were largely similar among all three vaccines in the CDC's data.

node.title: Biden to meet with Ukrainian refugees in Poland
node.description: The president will also deliver a "major address" while in Poland, according to his national security adviser.

node.title: Ukrainian woman recalls moment her home was destroyed by rocket
node.description: "We will fight till the end — as best we can," she said.

node.title: Silicon Valley's latest "unicorn" is a Bored Ape
node.description: Betting on the power of the blockchain, investors are pouring billions of dollars into NFT startups.

node.title: The motivation and the fears of an Ohio man helping Ukraine fight Putin
node.description: Alex Kalemba left Cincinnati for Ukraine as soon as Russian tanks started rolling over the border – one of many foreigners and civilians standing up to Putin's invasion.

node.title: Ukraine says Russian strike on Mariupol theater killed 300 people
node.description: The theater in the besieged port city was apparently being used as a bomb shelter by about 1,300 people when it was destroyed by Russian fire.

node.title: Parents of murdered boy celebrate son's memory with his favorite treat
node.description: The parents of Derrick Robie have made an extraordinary choice – to let go of decades of anger so they can begin to heal.

node.title: California man accused of smuggling 1,700 reptiles into U.S.
node.description: Baby crocodiles and Mexican beaded lizards were among the animals smuggled from Mexico and Hong Kong, feds say.

node.title: Parents of murdered boy find solace in ice cream with sprinkles
node.description: The parents of Derrick Robie have made an extraordinary choice – to let go of decades of anger so they can begin to heal.

node.title: Duckworth pushes for WWII memorial to women who worked on home front
node.description: Senator and combat war veteran pushes Senate for memorial for the "Rosie the Riveters" who worked as "letter carriers, code breakers, manufacturers and more."

node.title: Eric Smith, 13, when he murdered a child, back in the headlines
node.description: Smith, who spent 28 years behind bars for the 1993 murder of 4-year-old Derrick Robie, was released from prison in February. A look back at the notorious case.

node.title: I-D thieves socking victims with tax bills for money the crooks make
node.description: They tell the IRS their victims are the ones who got the income and hence, have the tax tab.
